title: Edwardsville, Illinois
text:
Edwardsville is a city in and the <a href="county%20seat">county seat</a> of <a href="Madison%20County%2C%20Illinois">Madison County</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, United States. As of the 2020 census, the population was 26,808. The city was named in honor of <a href="Ninian%20Edwards">Ninian Edwards</a>, then Governor of the Illinois Territory.
<a href="Southern%20Illinois%20University%20Edwardsville">Southern Illinois University Edwardsville</a>, the Edwardsville Arts Center, the "Edwardsville Journal", the "<a href="Madison%20County%20Record">Madison County Record</a>", and the "<a href="Edwardsville%20Intelligencer">Edwardsville Intelligencer</a>" are based here. <a href="Edwardsville%20High%20School">Edwardsville High School</a> and Metro-East Lutheran High School serve students in the area. Edwardsville also serves as the headquarters for <a href="Prairie%20Farms%20Dairy">Prairie Farms Dairy</a> one of the largest dairy cooperatives in the United States and ranked in the top 10 of the largest privately held companies in the St. Louis region. 
Edwardsville is a part of <a href="Southern%20Illinois">Southern Illinois</a> and the <a href="Metro%20East">Metro East</a> region within <a href="Greater%20St.%20Louis">Greater St. Louis</a>, located northeast of downtown St. Louis. It is part of the Edwardsville School District, which also includes the villages of <a href="Glen%20Carbon%2C%20Illinois">Glen Carbon</a>, <a href="Hamel%2C%20Illinois">Hamel</a> and <a href="Moro%2C%20Illinois">Moro</a>, as well as the <a href="township">township</a> areas around them.
History.
Edwardsville was incorporated in 1818. The first European-American settler was Thomas Kirkpatrick, who came in 1805, laid out a community, and served as the Justice of the Peace. He named the community after his friend <a href="Ninian%20Edwards">Ninian Edwards</a>, then territorial governor of Illinois. (Illinois did not become a state until 1818.) The <a href="Edwards%20Trace">Edwards Trace</a>, a key trail in the settlement of <a href="Central%20Illinois">Central Illinois</a>, used Edwardsville as a northward launching point.
In 1868 <a href="The%20Bank%20of%20Edwardsville">The Bank of Edwardsville</a> was founded. It was purchased by Champaign, Illinois-based <a href="Busey%20Bank">Busey Bank</a> in 2019.
In 1890, St. Louis industrialist N.O. Nelson chose a tract of land just south of Edwardsville to build plumbing factories. He also built a model workers' cooperative village called <a href="LeClaire%20Historic%20District">Leclaire</a>. He offered workers fair wages with reasonable working hours and a share of the profits. He named the village in honor of the French economist <a href="Edme-Jean%20Leclaire">Edme-Jean Leclaire</a>. The village also provided educational and recreational opportunities and made it financially possible for anyone to own a home. Unlike company towns such as Pullman near Chicago, the welfare and quality of life for the workers and their families was a major concern.
In 1934, the Village of Leclaire was incorporated into the City of Edwardsville. The area has a lake and park, baseball field, and the Edwardsville Children's Museum in the former Leclaire schoolhouse. Several Nelson factory buildings were renovated and adapted for use as the historic N. O. Nelson Campus of <a href="Lewis%20and%20Clark%20Community%20College">Lewis and Clark Community College</a>. The recognized Historic District has been listed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a>.
Each year on the third Sunday in October, the Friends of Leclaire host the annual Leclaire Parkfest with food, live heritage music, historic displays & tours, artisans, children's activities, a book sale, and more.
In 1983, Edwardsville's historic Saint Louis Street was also listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Dating back to 1809, this Historic District has a mile-long visual landscape. More than 50 historic homes date from the middle 19th century to early 20th century. The protection and preservation of Saint Louis Street is overseen by the <a href="Historic%20Saint%20Louis%20Street%20Association">Historic Saint Louis Street Association</a>.
Five Illinois governors came from Edwardsville: namesake Ninian Edwards, who became a territorial governor in 1809 and later served as governor from 1826 to 1830; <a href="Edward%20Coles">Edward Coles</a>, elected in 1822 and a strong opponent of <a href="slavery">slavery</a>; <a href="John%20Reynolds%20%28Illinois%20politician%29">John Reynolds</a>, governor from 1830 to 1834; <a href="Thomas%20Ford%20%28politician%29">Thomas Ford</a>, governor from 1842 to 1846; and <a href="Charles%20Deneen">Charles Deneen</a>, governor from 1909 to 1913.
Former president <a href="Abraham%20Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a> was in Edwardsville twice, as an attorney in the 1814 courthouse and a speaker outside the 1857 courthouse on Sept. 11, 1858. The present county courthouse, a square, four-story neoclassical structure of white marble that rises to six stories at the back section, was constructed from 1913 to 1915.
A 2010 issue of "<a href="Family%20Circle">Family Circle</a>" magazine named Edwardsville third of their "Top 10 Best Towns for Families."
Edwardsville was heavily affected by the <a href="Tornado%20outbreak%20of%20December%2010%E2%80%9311%2C%202021">Tornado outbreak of December 10–11, 2021</a>. An <a href="Amazon%20%28company%29">Amazon</a> warehouse collapsed and six workers were killed and many others injured.
Geography and climate.
According to the 2010 census, Edwardsville has an area of , of which (or 97%) is land and (or 3%) is water.
In recent years, average temperatures in the county seat of Edwardsville have ranged from a low of in January to a high of in July, although a record low of was recorded in January 1977 and a record high of was recorded in July 2012. Average monthly precipitation ranged from in January to in May. Climate Zone 4A per the International Energy Conservation Code.
Demographics.
As of the <a href="census">census</a> of 2005, 24,047 people, 7,975 households, and 5,199 families resided in the city. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> was 1,549.2 people per square mile (598.2/km2). There were 8,331 housing units at an average density of 600.6 per square mile (231.9/km2). The city's racial makeup was 87.70% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">White</a>, 8.66% <a href="African%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">African American</a>, 1.69% <a href="Asian%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 0.28% <a href="Native%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 0.03% <a href="Pacific%20Islander%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Pacific Islander</a>, 0.29% from <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 1.35% from two or more races. <a href="Hispanic%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Latino%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Latino</a> of any race were 1.00% of the population.
There were 10,000 households, out of which 32.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 52.4% were <a href="Marriage">married couples</a> living together, 9.9% had a female householder with no husband present, and 34.8% were non-families. 25.9% of all households were made up of individuals, and 8.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.44, and the average family size was 2.99.
The population was spread out, with 22.6% under the age of 18, 16.0% from 18 to 24, 29.4% from 25 to 44, 20.3% from 45 to 64, and 11.7% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 33 years. For every 100 females, there were 87.5 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 83.3 males.
The city's median household income was $50,921, and the median family income was $65,555. Males had a median income of $47,045 versus $29,280 for females. The city's <a href="per%20capita%20income">per capita income</a> was $26,510. About 5.0% of families and 8.6% of the population were below the <a href="poverty%20line">poverty line</a>, including 7.3% of those under age 18 and 6.0% of those age 65 or over.
Media.
Pop culture.
Scenes for the movie "<a href="The%20Lucky%20Ones%20%28film%29">The Lucky Ones</a>", starring <a href="Tim%20Robbins">Tim Robbins</a> and <a href="Rachel%20McAdams">Rachel McAdams</a>, were filmed in downtown Edwardsville in June 2007. However, the scene filmed was set in <a href="Denver%2C%20Colorado">Denver, Colorado</a>, and banners were hung on Edwardsville's Main Street that read, "Welcome to Denver."
Scenes for the 1978 film "<a href="Stingray%20%28film%29">Stingray</a>" were filmed in downtown Edwardsville, as well as in neighboring <a href="Alton%2C%20Illinois">Alton, Illinois</a>. Actor <a href="Christopher%20Mitchum">Christopher Mitchum</a>, second son of <a href="Robert%20Mitchum">Robert Mitchum</a>, starred in the film. (This film is not to be confused with "<a href="Corvette%20Summer">Corvette Summer</a>", released in the same year.)
Singer-songwriter <a href="Jackson%20Browne">Jackson Browne</a> recorded "Cocaine" and "Shaky Town" in Edwardsville's <a href="Holiday%20Inn">Holiday Inn</a> Room 124 for his album "<a href="Running%20on%20Empty%20%28album%29">Running on Empty</a>". The Holiday Inn at 3080 S. Route 157 was torn down and rebuilt as a <a href="Comfort%20Suites">Comfort Suites</a>.
A collection of poetry by Nigerian writer <a href="Kola%20Tubosun">Kọ́lá Túbọ̀sún</a>, "Edwardsville by Heart" (Wisdom's Bottom Press, November 2018), was based on the time the author spent in Edwardsville for three years as a Fulbright Scholar and student. The book was described by <a href="Howard%20Rambsy%20II">Howard Rambsy II</a> of <a href="Southern%20Illinois%20University%20Edwardsville">Southern Illinois University Edwardsville</a> as “an artistic map disguised as a volume of poetry”, and by <a href="Ainehi%20Edoro">Ainehi Edoro</a>, writing in <a href="Brittle%20Paper">Brittle Paper</a>, as "a magical meeting place of travelogue, memoir, and poetry."
An episode of the TV series "<a href="House%20Hunters">House Hunters</a>" was filmed in Edwardsville and aired in January 2018. The episode featured a local couple, Zach and Hannah, who grew up and went to school in Edwardsville.
